title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 7 june [1866]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 7 June [1866]
text: 7 June 1866June 7 thursdayThursdayDear Walt i have just receevedreceived your favor as the business men say enclosing 3 dollerdollars every thing comes correct lately sometimes i am almost inclined to think the old letter carrier was the guilty party this present one said the old one resinedresigned may beemaybe he had too) it is now about 11 oclocko'clock matty has been out hunting for a girl i doodo hope she will get one) for i help her somtimessometimes when i feel hardly able to stand up she has very much to doodo but it has got to such a pass that she depends totoo much on me if i felt strong and well i would not mind it she is kind to me but somtime i dontdon't feel like dooingdoing so much) Jeff looks bad he dontdon't complain but i think he ought to have a month of leave from all cares and anxieties his salary has been put up to 200 dolerdollars a month but their expencesexpenses is very great i dontdon't know what davis will pay probably 50 per month it aintain't none totoo much he has a mr somebody here quite often to supper and stay all night) i wrote a letter to han yesterday and enclosed a short note to the honorable mr Heyde as i received a very lengthy epistle from him the other day i really think the world never produced such another man or devil i think he is nearest the last named i wrote very short with no compliment that was not surprised at his wishing to get rid of han that he had expressed that wish many times before this letter but i had never made any reply not wishing to interfere with family difficulties but in all probability he would get his desire) he said every thing that he could say in his letter to me and he was going away that he should take care of himself and she could take care of herself that all the pleasure he had was with his fellow artists) George and smith and french the mason has bought 5 lots on portland ave opposite the arsenal 950 a lot going to put up brick houses i think george will get married he thinks he is very sly but murder will out your motherL Whi i am sorry Walt your head troubles you again dontdon't you think itsit's the blood rushes to the head doodo see some doctor walt Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 7 June [1866]
